pullRequest.body:
This change allows cleaning up one `rfl`

[Zulip thread](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Should.20.60Set.2Einclusion.60.20be.20an.20.60abbrev.60.3F/near/462205622)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Let's see the performance impact

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [749c95305e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15812/commits/749c95305ec4a0e80ea370a69ee79d13fdd93f85)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`- inclusion`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/92477345-291f-4d5e-bde5-2404ddc769b2) for commit d79ae4ccf7de8e48eb0d80dbf554b432f49ac0d9.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/ee4037fd-4d73-4aab-a0cd-1b8df6372aca/to/92477345-291f-4d5e-bde5-2404ddc769b2) against commit 173d2e189fd79bd332fb19bffac0dce43ec8acb8.

Besides cleaning up one messy proof (that can probably be cleaned up without making `inclusion` an `abbrev`), the win doesn't seem super clear to me. The def seems a little easier to read that a function with an invisible coercion in, and `simp` gets rid of `inclusion` anyway once you case on the right variables.
Ok, strong majority win then.

General information: ```text build: -2.1430 * 10⁹ (-0.00174%) ``` 1 file got slower by at least 10⁹ instructions: ```text Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.Restrict: +1.0597 * 10⁹ (+1.23%) ``` 1 file got slower by at least 10%: ```text Mathlib.Topology.Sheaves.Sheafify: +13.3% ``` 3 files got faster by at least 10⁹ instructions: ```text Mathlib.Algebra.Star.NonUnitalSubalgebra: -2.4904 * 10⁹ (-1.28%) Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.NonUnitalSubalgebra: -1.2540 * 10⁹ (-1.24%) Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.Subalgebra.Directed: -1.1011 * 10⁹ (-6.41%) ``` No file got faster by at least 10%.

What's up with the
```quote
1 file got slower by at least 10%:

    Mathlib.Topology.Sheaves.Sheafify:                                    +13.3%
```
It went from 7B to 7.9B

I think this is a prime use case for an abbreviation, it allows writing a simple yet abstract string of symbols `⟨x, h x.2⟩` in a human readable way. If the performance issues aren't major, then LGTM.

I tend to agree with Eric here that the point of `Set.inclusion` is to use it unapplied, else it gets simped away. This matters in simp lemmas, as then being able to index on `Set.inclusion` is important, eg [`Set.range_inclusion`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.range_inclusion) would see its key become `Set.range ?_` after this PR.
That's a good point. Approval revoked.

> I tend to agree with Eric here that the point of `Set.inclusion` is to use it unapplied, else it gets simped away. This matters in simp lemmas, as then being able to index on `Set.inclusion` is important, eg [`Set.range_inclusion`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.range_inclusion) would see its key become `Set.range ?_` after this PR.

Sure, but when you index correctly on subtypes, it turns out to be more painful than useful.
Mind expanding? I'm not sure what "indexing correctly on subtypes" amounts to here.
leanprover/lean4#5020
What's the trick for finding out the index computed for a simp lemma?
`#discr_tree_simp_key my_lemma` and `#discr_tree_key myInstance`
There is also a tactic which does it for the goal state which I might PR to mathlib at some point.
I created #15819 with the same proof: the porting note was just wrong, it works fine.

pullRequest.title: chore(Set.Basic): make `Set.inclusion` an `abbrev`

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
!bench

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/92477345-291f-4d5e-bde5-2404ddc769b2) for commit d79ae4ccf7de8e48eb0d80dbf554b432f49ac0d9.

Besides cleaning up one messy proof (that can probably be cleaned up without making `inclusion` an `abbrev`), the win doesn't seem super clear to me. The def seems a little easier to read that a function with an invisible coercion in, and `simp` gets rid of `inclusion` anyway once you case on the right variables.

General information: ```text build: -2.1430 * 10⁹ (-0.00174%) ``` 1 file got slower by at least 10⁹ instructions: ```text Mathlib.AlgebraicGeometry.Restrict: +1.0597 * 10⁹ (+1.23%) ``` 1 file got slower by at least 10%: ```text Mathlib.Topology.Sheaves.Sheafify: +13.3% ``` 3 files got faster by at least 10⁹ instructions: ```text Mathlib.Algebra.Star.NonUnitalSubalgebra: -2.4904 * 10⁹ (-1.28%) Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.NonUnitalSubalgebra: -1.2540 * 10⁹ (-1.24%) Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.Subalgebra.Directed: -1.1011 * 10⁹ (-6.41%) ``` No file got faster by at least 10%.

```quote
1 file got slower by at least 10%:

```
It went from 7B to 7.9B

I think this is a prime use case for an abbreviation, it allows writing a simple yet abstract string of symbols `⟨x, h x.2⟩` in a human readable way. If the performance issues aren't major, then LGTM.

I tend to agree with Eric here that the point of `Set.inclusion` is to use it unapplied, else it gets simped away. This matters in simp lemmas, as then being able to index on `Set.inclusion` is important, eg [`Set.range_inclusion`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.range_inclusion) would see its key become `Set.range ?_` after this PR.

> I tend to agree with Eric here that the point of `Set.inclusion` is to use it unapplied, else it gets simped away. This matters in simp lemmas, as then being able to index on `Set.inclusion` is important, eg [`Set.range_inclusion`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Set/Image.html#Set.range_inclusion) would see its key become `Set.range ?_` after this PR.

Sure, but when you index correctly on subtypes, it turns out to be more painful than useful.
Mind expanding? I'm not sure what "indexing correctly on subtypes" amounts to here.
leanprover/lean4#5020
What's the trick for finding out the index computed for a simp lemma?
`#discr_tree_simp_key my_lemma` and `#discr_tree_key myInstance`
There is also a tactic which does it for the goal state which I might PR to mathlib at some point.
